title: Verb chaining
tutorial: Verb chains or verb chaining is when there are two or more verbs in one sentence. When this occurs, only the first verb in the sentence is conjugated in the personal form. The other verbs are in the infinitive form. The exception to this rule is with the verbs täytyy and pitää.

nativeLang: Do you know how to code well?
Can you help me create a web site?
Are you able to help me create a web site?
I would like to know how to speak Finnish better
I would like to know how to speak better Finnish
I don't have time to do homework
Do you dare to go there alone?
Remember to call him/her
We plan to travel on holiday to Italy
We intend to travel on holiday to Italy
We plan to travel to Italy on holiday
We intend to travel to Italy on holiday
I will try to find it from somewhere
It is worth to try to ask that
It is worth trying to ask that
You can take coffee or tea from there
You can take from there coffee or tea
foreignLang: Saat ottaa tuosta kahvia tai teetä

nativeLang: Next week we start to study verb chaining
Next week we get to study verb chaining
I intend to change job
Do you feel like walking/jogging in the evening?
We decided to reschedule everything next week
Could you come here for a minute?
Where do you want to go?
We want to go home
When do you want to start?
We want to start straight away
We want to start at once
Whom are you trying to call?
I tried to call dad
I'm trying to call father
How did you manage to wake up so early?
How did you have the energy to wake up so early?
I managed to wake up just fine
foreignLang: Minä jaksoin herätä niin aikaisin ihan hyvin

nativeLang: What do you have time to do at home?
We have time to make food
When can you come here?
I can come in the evening
Why can't you come on the course today?
foreignLang: Miksi et voi tulla tännään kurssille?

nativeLang: I can't come because I am sick
foreignLang: Minä en voi tulla koska olen sairas

nativeLang: Do you know how to play chess?
I don't know how to play chess
What did you decide to buy her?
I decided to buy her flowers
Did you dare to ask her out?
I did dare to ask her out
Did you remember to put the letter in the postbox?
I remembered to put the letter in the post box
What did you forget to take?
I forgot to take my busspass
When does the weather start to get warm?
The weather starts to get warm in April
What do you need to get from the postoffice?
I need to get a packet from the postoffice
What do you need to do in the evening?
I need to do the homework in the evening
I need to do homework in the evening
What do you need to buy?
I need to buy milk
What don't you need to do?
I don't need to make food

title: Liking things
tutorial:
Tykätä/Pitää both mean to like. Tykätä is used more in spoken Finnish.

With nouns

You can use Tykätä/Pitää to express you like something or someone. Just add -sta/-stä to the end of the noun.

With verbs

To express you like doing something, you use either tykätä or pitää. However, the verb ending will differ depending on the which verb you use.

Just like there are different ways to express liking to do something in English, there are different ways in Finnish. For example, I like to ski and I like skiing, both mean the same thing. In Finnish though, you only use the infinitive verb form with tykätä. So, I like to ski is tykkään hiihtää. With pitää, you need to add -misesta/-misestä to the verb root. This then translates to verb-ing. So, pidän hiihtämisestä means, I like skiing.

But there's more! You can also add -sta/-stä, which changes the verb to a noun. For example, Tykkään hiihdosta and Pidään hiihdosta both mean, I like skiing. So in this context, I like skiing can mean you like to watch people doing it (perhaps at a sporting event, not necessarily as a participant), or as a participant. However, it's not as easy as adding -sta/-stä to the verb root. There is some kind of gnarly mutation between the verb root and -sta/-stä, which I can't currently explain.

nativeLang: I like to eat
I like eating
I like eating cake
I like to eat cake
I like to code
I like coding
I like coding web applications
I like to code web applications
I like to run
I like running
I like running in the forest
I like to run in the forest
I like to ride a bike
I like riding a bike
I like cycling
I like cycling
I like dessert
I like dogs
I like Mikko
I like him/her
I like them
I like bicyles
I don't like cats
I don't like fish
I don't like fish
I don't like fishing
I don't like to fish
I don't like shopping
I don't like to shop
